qas.question: In England, which arm would generally show two distinct sections, choir and presbytery?
Who is a projecting Lady Chapel dedicated to?
What shape does the eastern end often exhibit in France?
What is the ring of chapels found in the eastern end of French chapels known as?
In Italy, the eastern projection beyond the transept often contains what?
Which arm in England would generally show no distinct sections?
Who was a projecting Lady Chapel meant to harm?
What shape does the eastern end rarely exhibit in France?
What is the sphere of chapels found in the eastern end of French chapels known as?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>The eastern arm<b5_0/><a0_0/> shows considerable diversity. In England it is generally long and may have two distinct sections, both choir and presbytery. It is often square ended or has a projecting Lady Chapel, dedicated to <a1_0><b6_0>the Virgin Mary<b6_0/><a1_0/>. In France the eastern end is often <a2_0><b7_0>polygonal<b7_0/><a2_0/> and surrounded by a walkway called an ambulatory and sometimes a ring of chapels called a "<a3_0><b8_0>chevet<b8_0/><a3_0/>". While German churches are often similar to those of France, in Italy, the eastern projection beyond the transept is usually just a shallow apsidal chapel containing <a4_0>the sanctuary<a4_0/>, as at Florence Cathedral.
